#Text=Pedro de Aguado
#Text=Pedro de Aguado ( 1513 or 1538 – late 16th or early 17th century ) was a Spanish Franciscan friar who spent around 15 years in the New Kingdom of Granada , preaching to the indigenous people .

#Text=During this time he collected source material for a history of the region , and began a manuscript , Recopilación historial , which he completed in Spain between 1576 and 1583 but was unable to publish .
#Text=The manuscript was used by other historians , but was not published until the twentieth century . [ 1 ]
#Text=Biography
#Text=De Aguado 's date of birth is uncertain .
#Text=He is believed by Juan Friede to have been baptised in Valdemoro on 26 January 1513 , whilst Guillermo Morón argues for 16 February 1538 . [ 2 ] [ 3 ]

#Text=Arriving in the New World in 1560 or 1561 in Cartagena , his movements are uncertain until his arrival in Bogotá in 1571 , although it is likely he soon left Cartagena to minister to the Muisca .
#Text=By around 1564 he was a pastor to the Muisca at Cogua , and he was able to build two churches there .
#Text=Cogua was considered the first Indian town in New Granada where all the Indians were converted to Christianity , an achievement of Aguado 's recognised by King Philip II . [ 4 ]
#Text=In 1571 , De Aguado moved to Bogotá , and became a " minister provincial " of the local Franciscan Province .
#Text=In 1575 , De Aguado was sent by the Province on a mission to Spain to answer charges that the local monks were greedy and abusive . [ 1 ]
#Text=He was not able to leave Spain to return to Bogotá until 1583 . [ 1 ]
#Text=During this time he developed a manuscript on the history of the region , Recopilación historial , begun during his " idle hours " in Bogotá .
#Text=It is likely that Part I , on Santa Marta and the New Kingdom of Granada , was written in Bogotá , and Part II , on Venezuela and Cartagena , in Spain . [ 1 ]
#Text=De Aguado tried unsuccessfully to secure publication over a number of years .

#Text=A series of bureaucratic hurdles around censorship were complicated by a change in the rules , invalidating the royal licence to print which de Aguado obtained in 1581 , while a second licence in 1582 was complicated by a new requirement to have the printed copy checked against the original manuscript signed off by the king 's secretary .
#Text=Financial difficulties also played a role , but a definitive reason for publication failing to materialise is not known .

#Text=A planned Part III appears to have been abandoned , possibly in frustration at the difficulties with publication , with the witness statements that would have been the source material left in Spain on his return to Bogotá in 1583 . [ 1 ]
#Text=Dates for De Aguado 's death are even less certain than those for his birth ; dates vary from 1589 [ 5 ] to 1595 [ 6 ] to 1608 . [ 7 ]

#Text=After his death , his work was used directly and indirectly by other authors , notably by Fray Pedro Simón , who appears to have had access to a copy of Part II of the manuscript which de Aguado took with him on his return to Bogotá . [ 1 ]

#Text=The manuscript De Aguado left in Spain was obtained in the late eighteenth century by the historian Juan Bautista Muñoz ; his collection became part of the University of Valencia on his death , and was transferred to the Real Academia de la Historia after the university was partly destroyed in 1812 during a French siege of Valencia .
#Text=There , the manuscript was discovered in 1845 by Joaquín Acosta , and it was consulted by some historians in the latter part of the nineteenth century .
#Text=However , it was not published until 1906 ( Part I , Historia de Santa Marta y Nuevo Reino de Granada ) and 1913 ( Part II , Historia de Venezuela ) . [ 1 ] [ 7 ]
#Text=Works
#Text=Historia de Santa Marta y Nuevo Reino de Granada ( 1906 ) ( Part I , Part II – 1916/17 edition by Jerónimo Bécker )
#Text=Historia de Venezuela ( 1913 ) ( Part I , Part II – 1918/19 edition by Jerónimo Bécker )
